content.webTitle: Adam Yates: ‘I’ll be close to the back, working out who looks good’

fields.headline: Adam Yates: ‘I’ll be close to the back, working out who looks good’
fields.bodyText: Throughout the mountain stages of the Tour de France, the French television commentators watched Adam Yates climbing at the back of the general classification contenders group with consternation. The 23-year-old from Bury was struggling, he did not have the look of a man on a good day, he might be on the point of cracking. In fact, every time the main group around Froome hit a major ascent, Yates did the same thing: he pedalled at a rhythm that suited him and rode in the way he always has. “I’ve done that all my life,” he says. “Not just at the Tour: watch any other race in the last two and a half years and I’ll be close to the back looking at the group, working out who looks good. It’s the way I like to ride. It works for me.” His discreet style has earned him a nickname, The Shadow, which he says, “is weird, but I’ll take it”. Just before the start of the final stage, Yates was on the point of becoming the first Briton to wear the White Jersey of best under-25 to Paris in the competition’s 41-year history. Past winners include Francesco Moser, Laurent Fignon, Greg LeMond and Andy Hampsten. His fourth place overall equals Robert Millar’s in 1984 and has only ever been bettered by Chris Froome and Sir Bradley Wiggins. In British terms, this is remarkable and it should not go unnoticed merely because Froome and Wiggins have set the bar so high; at least, it is worth comparing with Tom Simpson’s sixth place overall in his first Tour finish in 1962. “I feel good, we’re here, it’s all done. It’s all been good experience. The plan wasn’t to ride for general classification at the start, but we rolled with it,” Yates said. He added that the decision to switch from targeting stages to aiming for a high overall placing came after he moved into second overall in the Pyrenees. Clearly, he has relished the learning process. “Every day there has been something new, trying to save energy in the bunch; sometimes it’s hard to relax when there is so much stress so you have to learn to stay calm under pressure. Orica hasn’t been a general classification team, but it’s become more and more [that way] oriented over the race, all the team have been learning as well.” Indeed, on Saturday, when Yates’s overall place was under threat from Roman Kreuziger, Orica could be seen working at the front on his behalf. Understandably, Yates is reticent over the prospect of attempting to win the Tour in future, playing down the notion in the same style as his team manager, Matt White. “I hope in the future I can try for the win, but I have got a couple of years before [that], I’m only 23, this is my second Tour and I’ve come fourth, but I can’t imagine trying to win it all of a sudden. It’s not just about improving my climbing, it’s about time trialling, saving energy, riding in the wind – there are a lot of things I can work on.” Yates had one off day in the three weeks, on Friday’s stage to Saint-Gervais, where he slipped off the podium after having trouble with his gears. Of an episode that sums up the learning process, he said: “I had a bike change, the pace went up for some reason” – the Astana team decided to hit the front of the peloton hard – “and it took a long time to come back. You waste a lot of energy, 100 kilometres from the finish, but that’s the Tour, those are the efforts you pay for in the end. But I’ll take one bad day out of 20.”
